qas.question: Which crevasses form on the edge of the glacier?
Why do marginal crevasses form on the edge of a glacier?

answers.text: reduction in speed caused by friction of the valley walls

qas.question: How are bergschrunds different than crevasses?

answers.text: singular features at a glacier's margins
where steeper slopes cause a glacier to accelerate

qas.question: What kind of crevasses form where steep slopes cause glaciers to deccelerate?
What kind of crevasses form where glaciers contract laterally?
What kind of crevasses form at the edge of a glacier due to an increase in speed?
What is formed when moving ice seperates from sragnant ice below?
What margins to crevasses form at?

context: Crevasses can form in several different ways. <b5_0>Transverse<b5_0/> crevasses are transverse to flow and form <a4_0>where steeper slopes cause a glacier to accelerate<a4_0/>. <b6_0>Longitudinal<b6_0/> crevasses form semi-parallel to flow where a glacier expands laterally. <a0_0><b7_0>Marginal<b7_0/> crevasses<a0_0/> form from the edge of the glacier, due to the <a1_0>reduction in speed caused by friction of the valley walls<a1_0/>. Marginal crevasses are usually largely transverse to flow. Moving glacier ice can sometimes separate from stagnant ice above, forming a <b8_0>bergschrund<b8_0/>. Bergschrunds resemble <a2_0>crevasses<a2_0/> but are <a3_0>singular features at a <b9_0>glacier's<b9_0/> margins<a3_0/>.
